article:
Dosage forms are a mixture of active drug components and nondrug components
(excipients). Depending on the method of administration they come in several
types. These are liquid dosage form, solid dosage form and semisolid dosage
forms. A 'Liquid dosage form' is the liquid form of a dose of a chemical
compound used as a drug or medication intended for administration or
consumption. Common dosage forms include pill, tablet, or capsule, drink or
syrup, and natural or herbal form such as plant or food of sorts, among many
others. Notably, the route of administration (ROA) for drug delivery is
dependent on the dosage form of the substance in question.

Various dosage forms may exist for a single particular drug, since different
medical conditions can warrant different routes of administration. For example,
persistent nausea and emesis or vomiting may make it difficult to use an oral
dosage form, and in such a case, it may be necessary to utilize an alternate
route such as inhalational, buccal, sublingual, nasal, suppository or
parenteral instead.

Additionally, a specific dosage form may be a requirement for certain kinds of
drugs, as there may be issues with various factors like chemical stability or
pharmacokinetics. As an example, insulin cannot be given orally because upon
being administered in this manner, it is extensively metabolized in the
gastrointestinal tract (GIT) before reaching the blood stream, and is thereby
incapable of sufficiently reaching its therapeutic target destinations. The oral
and intravenous doses of a drug such as paracetamol will differ for the same reason. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-
